story.storybody:
American ride-hailing firm Uber's motorcycle taxi service in Gurugram is brisk and lithe, helping travellers zip through traffic-choked roads at cheap rates.

But it's low on safety, with most of the two-wheelers bending rules by using the private number plates that have white backgrounds instead of the commercial yellow ones.

Experts say this renders the service illegal, which means a passenger is not entitled to any insurance in case of an accident.

VIOLATING THE LAW

Authorities last month seized over 50 motorcycles plying on the app-based company's UberMOTO platform after issuing a notice. Each violator will have to pay Rs 2,000 as fine.

A senior government official said a fresh notice will be issued to the company on Monday, giving it two days to clarify its stand. The California-headquartered multinational may have to terminate its two-wheeler service in Gurugram too after shutting it down in Bengaluru last month.

"Plying on white number plates is illegal and Uber has been found to be violating the law," Bhushan Kumar, assistant secretary at Gurugram's regional transport authority (RTA), told Mail Today. "Apart from seizing their vehicles we will take legal action against the company."

The previous notice was sent to Uber's chief executive officer, the president of Uber India and its general manager, north zone. The company is yet to reply.

WASHING OFF HANDS

Sources say the RTA may take legal action against the company. Plying of vehicles with private number plates for commercial purposes is punishable under provisions of the MV Act.

The company maintains that it has created a direct legal relationship between a customer and motorcycle driver, to which Uber is not a party.

"All responsibility and liabilities for any actions of the driver shall vest solely with him and shall, in no circumstance, be attributable to Uber." "How can an international company not take responsibility for their customers? This is a clear violation," a senior government official said.
